channel.title: KenSmith tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from KenSmith.

item.description: Red Square, 2008, Paul McCartney rocks a live "Back in the U.S.S.R." for the crowd, but Putin is unmoved. https://t.co/Jo3N380j8G at 0:15. https://t.co/aNRS5ftHnv

After a beautiful concert, I accidentally insulted the pianist, saying the performance was lovely and so athletic. Disapproval flashed on her face as she repeated the word athletic. (In my defense: there had been some wiping of the brow.) The nearby violinist did not comment. https://t.co/srFJkjS1XB
I readily confess that I don’t know how to talk about classical music.
A thread from @TheRaDR about a richer understanding of what it means to heal, and a book to follow. https://t.co/MGpS7jRX82 https://t.co/gSUofC3kmT
Thirty degrees colder here in northern Indiana than at this same time yesterday. https://t.co/DkX3SVTS47

@TheRaDR I remember my daughter and her friend sitting at the table mocking their junior high health book because they plainly saw how terrified the book/the society was of human bodies. They saw the book twist slyly away from discussing what they cared about. They mocked and mocked it.
@TheRaDR They saw, on some level, that the society was in the process of abandoning them and betraying them.

"They introduced their most extreme measures gradually—strategically—in order to gauge how each new outrage was received.... The doses became progressively stronger until all Europe finally perished from them.” https://t.co/RGOyWc70pO
Behaving like a traitor, the former president enthuses about Putin’s strategy moves . . . https://t.co/vMYr05whpN
Lately I have heard photographers say it four different ways. You take a photograph, make a photograph, find a photograph, or let a photograph find you. https://t.co/S0fcxLSI1L

From @MonaEltahowy: Nina Simone evokes two kinds of awareness raised by music: 1. You must now see us and see our life circumstances. https://t.co/KCZI5wJkse 2. You must know that we see you and the part you’ve played in shaping our life circumstances. https://t.co/hdlylaZYAz
If you’d like to take a live, in-nest eagle cam break or just check the weather on the Indiana-Michigan border. https://t.co/AhSc4XuUrI https://t.co/XCQ8bRoDzg

"Eventually, even well-meaning journalists and intellectuals became guilty of what he called “the ‘doping’ of excitement”—an artificial incitement of emotion that culminated, inevitably, in mass hatred and fear." From "When It’s Too Late to Stop Fascism" https://t.co/RGOyWc70pO
@baumansbrain @Columbia @thelineliterary I hope @TheLineLiterary Review got around to nominating this essay for the annual Best American Essays volume...
We can see now what society is like after collapse of "the Pottery Barn rule." https://t.co/TPqQZd21Wm
Some ways of telling the story feel disempowering. And so they probably are. It’s worth figuring out why that is.

The tragic and fearful character of our times is not something from which we can detach ourselves; we are in it, as fish are in the sea, whether we speak about it in our poems or not.” —Denise Levertov, a #SundaySentence

“At fifteen, I read a piece about the all-woman noise trio Babes in Toyland and knew the critic got it wrong and that I, a fan, could get it right. [My] entrance to music criticism was a rebuttal [and] much of my early career was me yelling But you’re wrong! over the transom.” https://t.co/Al4eyaNARB
“And what is the white heteropatriarchy if not the biggest algorithm of ’em all?” —Jessica Hopper in “The First Collection of Criticism by a Living Female Rock Critic” @JessHopp [link]
A brief report back from the afterlife. From “Angels & Saints” by Eliot Weinberger. [link]
What is the journey of advanced old age? Observing her own mother closely, poet Denise Levertov reports a few things about the life of some or many elders. [link]
Science and science communication, social media, creativity, inclusivity, and drag. [link]

Eleven years ago today… Out front, a yard or so of gray-black snow has melted down to the ground, revealing a snow-drowned Ophelia near the curb: the green, prone, flattened shape of our Christmas tree.

Early on a sunny Paris evening, summer of 1982, I set out to visit Père Lachaise Cemetery, but when I arrived it had already closed for the day. Dozens of famous people are buried there, but oddly I can no longer remember whose grave I planned to visit. Not the rock star, though. [link]

“Users have a special kind of insight that most news organizations don’t tap…. The challenge for news organizations [is] to learn how to incorporate the experience of these users and their new publishing tools, into their product — the news.” [link]
@RayBoomhower Thanks for bringing Jack Gilbert to mind today, by the way.
